facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2456 of 1966 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2456 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 27, 1964 of Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 299 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 27, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 299 of 1958.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. Indetermining the taxable income

facts.text: For assessment year 1948-49, Income-tax Officer added Rs. 1,60,000 as undisclosed receipts to respondent firm's income.

anchor.surface_text: . Indetermining the taxable income of the respondent firm for the assessment year 1948-49 the Income-tax Officer added to the income returned a sum of Rs. 1,60,000 as undisclosed receipts.

facts.text: Order adding Rs. 1,60,000 confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The order was confirmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and by the Tribunal. The Income-tax Officer had in the meantime commenced a proceeding

facts.text: Income-tax Officer levied penalty of Rs. 60,000 under s. 28(1)(c) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 on respondent firm.

anchor.surface_text: . The Income-tax Officer had in the meantime commenced a proceeding for the levy of penalty and in exercise of the power under s. 28  1   c  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 he directed the respondent firm to pay Rs. 60,000 as penalty.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the penalty order.

anchor.surface_text: . The Appellate Assistant Commissioner in appeal confirmed the order. The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal rejected the contention

facts.text: Tribunal rejected respondent's contention that penalty on dissolved firm was without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: . The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal rejected the contention of the respondent that the order imposing penalty upon the firm after the original firm was dissolved was without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to Patna High Court at instance of respondent firm.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal referred at the instance of the respondent firm the following question to the High Court of Patna for opinion Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case

facts.text: Question referred: Whether imposition of penalty under s. 28(1)(c) on petitioner firm (respondent) as constituted at time of levy was legal and valid.

anchor.surface_text: the imposition of penalty under s. 28  1   c  of the Indian Income-tax Act, upon the petitioner firm  respondent  as constituted at the time of levy of penalty was legal and valid?

facts.text: Firm dissolved on July 7, 1951 when Butto Kristo Roy died.

anchor.surface_text: The firm which carried on the business during the calendar year 1947 was dissolved on July 7, 1951 when Butto Kristo Roy, one of the partners, died.

facts.text: During previous year 1947, no instrument of partnership, but oral terms same as deed dated October 17, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: During the previous year 1947 there was no instrument of partnership in existence, but the terms of the oral partnership were the same as set out in the partnership deed dated October 17, 1949.

facts.text: Business continued from July 8, 1951 by new firm as successor, same terms and partners except Baidyanath Roy replaced Butto Kristo Roy.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the firm was continued with effect from July 8, 1951 by the new firm as successor to the business of the old firm. The terms of the partnership were the same as set out in the deed dated October 17, 1949 and the partners and their shares were also the same except that Baidyanath Roy took the place of Butto Kristo Roy.

facts.text: From April 28, 1952, business carried on by partnership of Baidyanath Roy and Bijali Kanti Roy under instrument dated August 27, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: With effect from April 28, 1952, the business was carried on by a partnership constituted by Baidyanath Roy and Bijali Kanti Roy under an instrument dated August 27, 1952.

facts.text: No dissolution of firm carrying on business, only change in constitution from April 28, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: There was no dissolution of the firm, which was carrying on the business there was only a change in the constitution of the old firm from April 28, 1952.

facts.text: Patna High Court held penalty could be levied only on original firm constituted in account year for 1948-49, not on new firm under deed dated April 27, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that penalty could be legally levied only upon the original firm constituted in the account year relevant to the assessment year 1948-49 and not upon the new firm constituted under the deed dated April 27, 1952.

facts.text: Penalty proceeding on firm in existence on July 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: partners of the firm in existence on July 30, 1954, were liable to be assessed to penalty as successors

facts.text: Appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Firm carried on business during calendar year 1947.

anchor.surface_text: that The firm which carried on the business during the calendar year 1947 was dissolved on July 7, 1951

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the imposition of penalty under s. 28(1)(c) of the Indian Income-tax Act, upon the petitioner firm (respondent) as constituted at the time of levy of penalty was legal and valid?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the imposition of penalty under s. 28  1   c  of the Indian Income-tax Act, upon the petitioner firm  respondent  as constituted at the time of levy of penalty was legal and valid?

issues.text: Whether the source of the power of the Income-tax Officer to impose a penalty was in section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court approached the problem before them on the assumption that the source of the power of the Income-tax Officer to impose a penalty was in section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

issues.text: Whether section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 applies to cases of discontinuance of the business of a firm or also where there is dissolution of the firm but not discontinuance of its business?

anchor.surface_text: Section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as it stood at the relevant date, in so far as it is material provided Where any business, profession or vocation carried on by a firm has been discontinued every person who was at the time of such discontinuance a partner of such firm shall,

issues.text: Whether assessment in Chapter IV of the Income-tax Act, 1922 includes a proceeding for imposition of penalty?

anchor.surface_text: Section 44 therefore only applied to those cases in which there had been discontinuance of the business and not to case, in which the business continued after reconstitution of the firm or there was succession to the business. Cases of reconstitution of the firm or succession to the business of the firm are covered by ss. 26(1) and (2). Assessment in Chapter IV of the Income-tax Act, 1922, includes a proceeding for imposition of penalty.

issues.text: Whether in the case of reconstitution of a firm, the Income-tax Officer is to assess the firm as constituted at the time of making the assessment including for imposition of penalty under s. 28?

anchor.surface_text: ss. 25(1), (2), 26(1), (2) and 28(1)(c) in some detail. The Court observed Section 44 operates in two classes of cases where there is discontinuance of business, profession or vocation carried on by a firm or association, and where there is dissolution of an association.

issues.text: Whether the question whether under s. 26 read with s. 28 penalty may be imposed upon the new firm was raised or argued before the Tribunal so as to be answerable in reference under s. 66?

anchor.surface_text: in a reference under s. 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, only the question which was either raised or argued before the Tribunal may be answered, even if the language of the question framed by the Tribunal may apparently include an enquiry into other matters which could have been, but were not, raised or argued.

arguments.claim: Section 44 applies to cases of discontinuance of the business of a firm and not where there is dissolution of the firm but not discontinuance of its business

anchor.surface_text: The section is fairly plain it applies to cases of discontinuance of the business of a firm and not where there is dissolution of the firm but not discontinuance of its business.

arguments.claim: s.44 only applies when there has been discontinuance of the business

anchor.surface_text: a Full Bench of the Madras High Court observed This section (s.44) only applies when there has been discontinuance of the, business, The section (1) says that if a business is discontinued the partners shall nevertheless be jointly and severally liable

arguments.claim: Section 44 operates in two classes of cases where there is discontinuance of business, profession or vocation carried on by a firm or association, and where there is dissolution of an association. Mere dissolution of a firm without discontinuance of the business will not attract s.44

anchor.surface_text: The Court observed Section 44 operates in two classes of cases where there is discontinuance of business, profession or vocation carried on by a firm or association, and where there is dissolution of an association. It follows that mere dissolution of a firm without discontinuance of the business will not attract the application of s.44 of the Act

arguments.claim: A firm whether registered or unregistered is recognised under the Act as a unit of assessment (sections 3 and 2(2)), and its income is computed under clauses (3) and (4) of section 23, as the income of any other unit

anchor.surface_text: A firm whether registered or unregistered is recognised under the Act as a unit of assessment sections 3 and 2(2), and its income is computed under clauses (3) and (4) of section 23. as the income of any other unit.

arguments.claim: The Income-tax Officer has under section 26(1) to assess the firm as constituted at the time of making the assessment

anchor.surface_text: The Income- tax Officer has under section 26(1) to assess the firm as constituted at the time of making the assessment, but the income, profits and gains of the previous year have, for the purpose of inclusion in the total income of the partners, to be apportioned between the partners who were entitled to receive the same.

arguments.claim: Discontinuance of business has the same connotation in section 44 as it has in section 25 of the Act it does not cover mere change in ownership or in the constitution of the unit of assessment

anchor.surface_text: Discontinuance of business has the same connotation in section 44 as if has in section 25 of the Act it does not cover mere change in ownership or in the constitution of the unit of assessment.

arguments.claim: by reconstitution of the firm, no change is brought in the personality of the firm, and succession to the business and not discontinuance of the business results

anchor.surface_text: by reconstitution of the firm, no change is brought in the personality of the firm, and succession to the business and not discontinuance of the business results But the Income-tax Act recognises a firm

arguments.claim: Assessment in Chapter IV of the Income-tax Act, 1922, includes a proceeding for imposition of penalty

anchor.surface_text: Assessment in Chapter IV of the Income-tax Act, 1922, includes a proceeding for imposition of penalty.

arguments.claim: If there is reconstitution of the firm, by virtue of s. 26, the Income-tax Officer will in imposing the penalty proceed against the firm. If there is discontinuance of the business penalty will be imposed against the partners of the firm

anchor.surface_text: If there is reconstitution of the firm, by virtue of s. 26, the Income-tax Officer will in imposing the penalty proceed against the firm. If there is discontinuance of the business penalty will be imposed against the partners of the firm.

arguments.claim: Before the Tribunal and the High Court the case was argued on the footing that s. 44 alone was applicable. Whether under the terms of s. 26 read with s. 28, penalty may be imposed upon the new firm was never investigated

anchor.surface_text: Before the Tribunal and the High Court the case was argued on the footing that s. 44 alone was applicable. Whether under the terms of s. 26 read with s. 28, penalty may be imposed upon the new partners for the failure of the partners of the firm constituted in the year of account relating to the assessment 1948-49 was never investigated.

arguments.claim: in a reference under s. 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, only the question which was either raised or argued before the Tribunal may be answered, even if the language of the question framed by the Tribunal may apparently include an enquiry into other matters which could have been, but were not, raised or argued

anchor.surface_text: in a reference under s. 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, only the question which was either raised or argued before the Tribunal may be answered, even if the language of the question framed by the Tribunal may apparently include an enquiry into other matters which could have been, but were not, raised or argued.

holdings.text: The Tribunal and the High Court were in error in assuming that the source of the power of the Income-tax Officer to impose a penalty was section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court approached the problem before them on the assumption that the source of the power of the Income-tax Officer to impose a penalty was in section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. In so assuming, in our judgment, they were in error.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 28 independently authorizes ITO to impose penalty in any proceeding under the Act; s.44 addresses only partner liability on business discontinuance.

holdings.text: Section 44 applies only to cases of discontinuance of the business of a firm and not where there is dissolution of the firm but not discontinuance of its business.

anchor.surface_text: Section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as it stood at the relevant date, in so far as it is material provided Where any business, profession or vocation carried on by a firm has been discontinued every person who was at the time of such discontinuance a partner of such firm shall,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain text of s.44 requires 'discontinued'; dissolution alone insufficient as business may continue.

holdings.text: Mere dissolution of a firm without discontinuance of the business will not attract the application of s.44 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Court observed Section 44 operates in two classes of cases where there is discontinuance of business, profession or vocation carried on by a firm or association, and where there is dissolution of an association. It follows that mere dissolution of a firm without discontinuance of the business will not attract the application of s.44 of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Act distinguishes discontinuance (s.44) from reconstitution (s.26); follows Shivram Poddar precedent.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer has under section 26(1) to assess the firm as constituted at the time of making the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Income- tax Officer has under section 26(1) to assess the firm as constituted at the time of making the assessment, but the income, profits and gains of the previous year have, for the purpose of inclusion in the total income of the partners, to be apportioned between the partners who were entitled to receive the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual mandate of s.26(1) for change in constitution; firm personality persists.

holdings.text: Assessment in Chapter IV of the Income-tax Act, 1922, includes a proceeding for imposition of penalty.

anchor.surface_text: Assessment in Chapter IV of the Income-tax Act, 1922, includes a proceeding for imposition of penalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Penalty levy is part of assessment process under Chapter IV provisions like ss.25,26.

holdings.text: If there is reconstitution of the firm, by virtue of s. 26, the Income-tax Officer will in imposing the penalty proceed against the firm; if discontinuance, against partners.

anchor.surface_text: If there is reconstitution of the firm, by virtue of s. 26, the Income-tax Officer will in imposing the penalty proceed against the firm. If there is discontinuance of the business penalty will be imposed against the partners of the firm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.28 penalty applies to firm as 'person'; s.26 dictates entity assessed on reconstitution vs s.44 on discontinuance.

holdings.text: In a reference under s.66, only questions raised or argued before the Tribunal may be answered.

anchor.surface_text: in a reference under s. 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, only the question which was either raised or argued before the Tribunal may be answered, even if the language of the question framed by the Tribunal may apparently include an enquiry into other matters which could have been, but were not, raised or argued.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limits scope of High Court reference to Tribunal record; s.26+s.28 not argued below.

holdings.text: Section 44 does not apply to this case as there was no discontinuance of business but continuation after reconstitution and succession.

anchor.surface_text: Section 44 therefore only applied to those cases in which there had been discontinuance of the business and not to case, in which the business continued after reconstitution of the firm or there was succession to the business. Cases of reconstitution of the firm or succession to the business of the firm are covered by ss. 26(1) and (2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show business continued post-1951 death via successor firm, then reconstitution in 1952; invokes s.26 not s.44.

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 44 only applies when there has been discontinuance of the business
precedents.cited_holding: This section (s.44) only applies when there has been discontinuance of the business. The section says that if a business is discontinued the partners shall nevertheless be jointly and severally liable for the profits which had been earned.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.44 applicable where there was discontinuance of business consequent upon dissolution, and ITO incompetent to levy penalty after discontinuance
precedents.cited_holding: there was discontinuance of the business of the firm consequent upon dissolution of the firm, s. 44 was held applicable, and it was held that imposition of penalty being a process of assessment the Income-tax Officer was not competent to levy penalty after discontinuance of the business

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court approached the problem before them on the assumption that the source of the power of the Income-tax Officer to impose a penalty was in section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. In so assuming, in our judgment, they were in error.

anchor.surface_text: The Court observed Section 44 operates in two classes of cases where there is discontinuance of business, profession or vocation carried on by a firm or association, and where there is dissolution of an association. It follows that mere dissolution of a firm without discontinuance of the business will not attract the application of s.44 of the Act
The appeal fails and is dismissed.

The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: in a reference under s. 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, only the question which was either raised or argued before the Tribunal may be answered, even if the language of the question framed by the Tribunal may apparently include an enquiry into other matters which could have been, but were not, raised or argued.
The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Section 44 therefore only applied to those cases in which there had been discontinuance of the business and not to case, in which the business continued after reconstitution of the firm or there was succession to the business. Cases of reconstitution of the firm or succession to the business of the firm are covered by ss. 26(1) and (2).
The appeal fails and is dismissed.
